title: 111_hr3923
content: The Act is titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines the terms "District" as the Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District of Boulder, Colorado, and "Federal land" as specific parcels in the National Forest. The Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District of Boulder, Colorado, is involved in a land exchange with the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado. The exchange includes a 3.56-acre parcel of federal land and a 5.17-acre parcel of non-federal land in Boulder County. The term "non-Federal land" refers to a 5.17-acre parcel in unincorporated Boulder County, Colorado, as depicted on a map dated November 12, 2009. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The text chunk "SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE." is a concise summary of a section related to a land exchange. The District can offer to convey non-Federal land to the Secretary, who will then convey Federal land to the District. The land exchange is subject to the provisions of the Act and follows applicable laws. The District can offer non-Federal land to the Secretary in exchange for Federal land, subject to applicable laws. The Secretary may accept a cash payment exceeding 25% of the land value, and the District must cover survey and appraisal costs. The District is responsible for paying for land surveys, appraisals, and administrative costs related to a land exchange with the Secretary. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights and any additional terms set by the Secretary. The land exchange under subsection (a) is subject to valid existing rights and any terms set by the Secretary. Congress intends for the exchange to be completed within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. If not completed within this timeframe, the Secretary has the authority to conduct the sale of federal land. If the land exchange under subsection (a) is not completed within 1 year, the Secretary may offer to sell the Federal land to the District for fair market value. The proceeds from the sale will be deposited in a designated fund. The Secretary may sell Federal land to the District for fair market value if the land exchange is not completed within 1 year. Proceeds from the sale will be deposited in a fund for land acquisition. Proceeds from the sale of Federal land to the District will be available to the Secretary for land acquisition in the National Forest. The acquired non-Federal land will be added to the National Forest and managed according to the Weeks Law. The Federal land sold to the District will be managed in accordance with the Weeks Law and other applicable laws. Any public order withdrawing the land from public use is revoked to allow for the conveyance to the District. The Federal land sold to the District will be managed according to the Weeks Law and other relevant laws. Any public order withdrawing the land is revoked to allow for its conveyance to the District. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 13, 2010, with Lorraine C. Miller as the Clerk.
